extracted_ttps.description: The attackers used phishing emails with lure documents to gain initial access to the victim's machine
indicators: Product Specification-Freight-Company Qualification Information wps-pdf Export.pdf.exe

extracted_ttps.description: Hydrochasma relies on living-off-the-land and publicly available tools to achieve persistent and stealthy access to victim machines
Hydrochasma uses command line tools like at, net, and ping to interact with the victim machine
Hydrochasma uses remote access tools like Cobalt Strike Beacon to interact with the victim machine

The attackers used Process Dumper (lsass.exe) to dump domain passwords
The attackers used the Gogo scanning tool to scan the network
The attackers used the AlliN scanning tool to scan the intranet
Use of Go-strip to make a Go binary smaller in size

Use of tunneling tools for command and control
Use of user execution for malware deployment
Use of Task Scheduler for automating tasks

rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: The attackers used phishing emails with lure documents to gain initial access to the victim's machine
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Suspicious User Execution via Offensive Tools and LOLBins
rules.description: Detects execution of known offensive tools (Cobalt Strike, Metasploit) and use of living-off-the-land binaries (at, net, ping) that may indicate adversary activity.
falsepositives: Administrative use of 'net' or 'at' commands for legitimate maintenance
Use of 'ping' for network diagnostics by users or scripts
Backup or monitoring tools invoking 'net' or 'at' in automated workflows

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Hydrochasma Command and Scripting Interpreter Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of command line tools like at, net, and ping by Hydrochasma to interact with the victim machine
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Network troubleshooting activities

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Remote Services - Cobalt Strike Beacon Detection
rules.description: Detects potential Cobalt Strike Beacon activity by identifying remote connections to known command and control servers
falsepositives: Legitimate HTTPS traffic to the specified IPs
Connections from backup agents or other authorized tools

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel via Cobalt Strike Beacon
rules.description: Detects potential exfiltration over C2 channel using Cobalt Strike Beacon by monitoring for processes connecting to known malicious IPs associated with the tool.
falsepositives: Administrative tools or scripts connecting to external IPs for diagnostics or updates (unlikely due to specific IPs)
Test traffic in controlled environments using these IPs (should be excluded via network segmentation)
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Protocol Tunneling via Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP)
rules.description: Detects the use of Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) for protocol tunneling, a technique used by attackers to expose a local server to the internet.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of FRP in development or testing environments

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Detection: Signed Binary Proxy Execution
rules.description: The attackers dropped a legitimate Microsoft Edge update file to execute malicious code
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Hydrochasma Data Gathering via Procdump
rules.description: Detects the use of Procdump to gather data from the local system, as used by Hydrochasma
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks using Procdump
Gaming or software development activities that involve process dumping

rules.title: OS Credential Dumping via LSASS

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tools interacting with lsass.exe

rules.title: Detection of NTLM Relay Attack for Validated Authentication Requests

rules.title: Scheduled Task Creation via schtasks.exe or PowerShell Register‑ScheduledTask
rules.description: Detects creation of Windows scheduled tasks using schtasks.exe with the /create flag or PowerShell Register‑ScheduledTask, indicating possible abuse of Task Scheduler for persistence or execution.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that create scheduled tasks using schtasks.exe
System maintenance or backup tools that register scheduled tasks via PowerShell
Enterprise automation platforms that schedule recurring jobs

attacks.command: echo "This is a benign lure document." > %TEMP%\lure.txt
attacks.description: Create a benign text file that could represent a lure document from a phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named lure.txt is created in the TEMP directory containing the specified text.

attacks.description: Use certutil to decode a file, simulating the decoding of a malicious payload from a phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of lure.txt are decoded and saved to decoded_lure.txt in the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to display a message box, simulating a phishing popup that might appear after a victim opens a malicious document.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box pops up with the text 'You have been phished.'

attacks.command: echo 'This is a test phishing email' > $HOME/phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Creates a text file named phishing_email.txt in the user's home directory with content that mimics a phishing email, for testing detection rules.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing_email.txt will be created in the user's home directory containing the specified text.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign PDF file from a specified URL to the user's home directory, simulating the download of a lure document from a phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: A PDF file named lure_document.pdf will be downloaded from the specified URL and saved in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Copies the phishing_email.txt file to the Documents directory, simulating the movement of a potentially malicious file within the system. The -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue parameter ensures the command does not fail if the Documents directory does not exist.
attacks.expected_behavior: The phishing_email.txt file will be copied to the Documents directory if it exists, or the command will silently continue if it does not.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using cmd.exe to create a test file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the user's temporary directory with the content 'Hello'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to display a message box.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message box with the text 'Hello, World!'.

attacks.description: Advanced command execution using net.exe to add a new user (requires admin privileges).
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a new user named 'testuser' with the password 'testpassword' to the system, requiring administrative privileges.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to create a test file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Test Payload'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command requiring admin privileges to write to a system directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to create a file named test.txt in /etc with the content 'Admin Test Payload', requiring sudo privileges.

attacks.description: Advanced command downloading and executing a script from a remote location.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script from https://example.com/test.sh and executes it using bash, simulating a potential attack vector.

attacks.description: Add a new user to the system using the net user command.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user named 'testuser' with the password 'testpassword' will be added to the system.

attacks.description: Display the privileges of the current user using the whoami command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the privileges of the current user.

attacks.description: Create a file in the temp directory using cmd.exe and echo command.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'test.txt' with the content 'Hello World!' will be created in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic command to execute 'ls' using 'at' command
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'ls' command will be executed after 1 minute and will list the files in the current directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to write a test file and execute 'cat' using 'at' command
attacks.expected_behavior: A test file will be written to the temporary directory and the 'cat' command will be executed after 2 minutes to display the contents of the test file.

attacks.command: at now + 3 minutes -f /usr/bin/touch /tmp/test2.txt; at now + 4 minutes -f /usr/bin/ls /tmp/test2.txt
attacks.description: Advanced command to schedule multiple commands using 'at' command
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'touch' command will be executed after 3 minutes to create a new test file, and the 'ls' command will be executed after 4 minutes to list the files in the temporary directory, including the newly created test file.

attacks.description: Lists all running services, which can be used to identify potential remote services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of currently running services on the local machine.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to filter and display only the services that are currently running, which can help in identifying active remote services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of names of services that are currently running on the local machine.

attacks.description: Queries the status of a service, which can be useful for checking the state of remote services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the status of services on the local machine, which can include information about whether they are running, stopped, or paused.

attacks.description: Simulate remote access to a victim machine using SSH and execute a basic command to list files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files on the victim machine.

attacks.description: Create a directory on the victim machine to simulate creating resources remotely.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new directory on the victim machine.

attacks.description: Copy a file to the victim machine using SCP to simulate transferring data remotely.
attacks.expected_behavior: Transfers the specified file to the victim machine.

attacks.description: Create a file in the temp directory and exfiltrate its contents using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named exfiltration.txt is created in the temp directory and its contents are printed to the console

attacks.description: Create a file in the temp directory and exfiltrate its contents using powershell
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named exfiltration.txt is created in the temp directory and its contents are printed to the console

attacks.description: Setting up a listener on port 8080 to receive exfiltrated data
attacks.expected_behavior: Data sent to this port will be saved to exfiltrated_data.txt

attacks.description: Exfiltrating the /etc/passwd file to the C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of /etc/passwd will be sent to the listener

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Exfiltrating compressed sensitive data to the C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: Compressed sensitive data will be sent to the attacker's netcat listener

attacks.description: Download and extract FRP on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: FRP will be downloaded and extracted, ready for configuration and use

attacks.description: Start the FRP server on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: The FRP server will start, listening for incoming connections

attacks.description: Start the FRP client on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: The FRP client will start, connecting to the FRP server and exposing the local server to the internet

attacks.description: Using certutil to download and execute a malicious file masquerading as a legitimate binary
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file from a specified URL, saves it as legitimate.exe in the temp directory, and then executes it.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to execute a malicious file disguised as a Microsoft Edge update
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes a file named MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe from the temp directory, simulating the execution of a malicious payload disguised as a legitimate update.

attacks.description: Creating a directory for a fake Microsoft Edge update, copying a malicious file into it, and then executing the malicious file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a directory for a fake update, copies a malicious file into it, and then executes the malicious file, demonstrating a more complex scenario of signed binary proxy execution.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to create a file with a test payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Test Payload'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that creates a script, makes it executable, and then executes it, demonstrating a more complex scenario of signed binary proxy execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script /tmp/test.sh, makes it executable, and then runs it, printing 'Test Payload' to the console.

attacks.command: bash -c '(echo "#!/bin/bash"; echo "echo Advanced Test Payload") > $HOME/test.sh; chmod +x $HOME/test.sh; $HOME/test.sh'
attacks.description: Advanced command execution that utilizes the user's home directory to create and execute a script, simulating a more sophisticated attack scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script test.sh in the user's home directory, makes it executable, and then executes it, printing 'Advanced Test Payload' to the console.

attacks.description: Gather detailed system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed system information, including OS version, processor, and memory.

attacks.description: Gather network configuration information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed network configuration information, including IP addresses, subnet masks, and default gateways.

attacks.description: Gather information about the current user
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays information about the current user, including the username, groups, and privileges.

attacks.description: Read the passwd file to gather user information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the contents of the passwd file

attacks.description: List the contents of the root directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the contents of the root directory, including hidden files

attacks.description: Gather process information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes

attacks.description: Lists all stored credentials for the current user.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of stored credentials in the command prompt.

attacks.description: Dumps the SAM registry hive to a file, which contains local account credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves the SAM registry hive to a file named 'sam.reg' in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Attempts to access the current user's token, which could be used for credential dumping or elevation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current user's token information in the PowerShell console.

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate credential dumping by searching for 'password' in /etc/passwd
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output lines containing 'password' from /etc/passwd, simulating a basic credential dump.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to simulate credential dumping by reading /etc/shadow
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the contents of /etc/shadow, which contains hashed passwords, simulating an intermediate credential dump.

attacks.description: Advanced command to simulate credential dumping using John the Ripper
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to crack passwords using John the Ripper, simulating an advanced credential dump. Note: This command requires John the Ripper to be installed and is for testing purposes only in isolated environments.

attacks.description: Lists all installed quick fix engineering (QFE) updates on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of installed updates without modifying the system.

attacks.description: Lists all running processes on the system in brief format.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes without affecting system performance.

attacks.description: Retrieves information about the operating system using PowerShell's Get-WmiObject cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about the operating system without modifying it.

attacks.description: Scan the local network to discover hosts using nmap.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command scans the specified IP range to identify active hosts, mimicking network discovery aspects of WMI.

attacks.description: Use arp-scan to discover devices on the local network.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses ARP requests to identify devices on the network, which can be part of a discovery process similar to WMI's capabilities.

attacks.description: Discover active hosts on the network using netdiscover.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command actively scans the network to find active hosts, which aligns with the discovery tactic of WMI.

attacks.description: View all active directory computers
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of active directory computers

attacks.description: Display all configured IP addresses on the local system
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed IP configuration information for all adapters

attacks.description: Perform a simple ping sweep of a specified subnet
attacks.expected_behavior: Pings each IP address in the specified subnet and displays the results

attacks.description: Basic network scan using nmap to discover hosts in the 192.168.1.0/24 subnet
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will scan the specified subnet and display a list of discovered hosts.

attacks.description: Intermediate DNS lookup using dig to resolve the IP address of google.com
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will perform a DNS lookup and display the IP address of google.com.

attacks.description: Advanced network scan using nmap to discover hosts, services, and operating systems in the 192.168.1.0/24 subnet
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will scan the specified subnet, display a list of discovered hosts, and attempt to identify the services and operating systems running on each host.

attacks.description: Encode a test file using certutil.exe to demonstrate obfuscation of file contents
attacks.expected_behavior: A new encoded file is created in the temp directory

attacks.description: Compress a test file to reduce its size, simulating the effect of making a binary smaller
attacks.expected_behavior: A new zip archive is created in the temp directory containing the test file

attacks.description: Create a file with a test string, then encode it to demonstrate obfuscation
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file with a test string is created, then an encoded version of this file is generated

attacks.command: go build -o example example.go; go-strip example
attacks.description: Compile a Go program and then use go-strip to minimize the binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: The size of the example binary will be reduced after go-strip is applied.

attacks.command: echo 'package main; import "fmt"; func main() { fmt.Println("Hello, World!") }' > example.go; go build -o example example.go; go-strip example
attacks.description: Create a simple Go program, compile it, and then apply go-strip to obfuscate.
attacks.expected_behavior: A 'Hello, World!' program will be compiled and then its binary size reduced.

attacks.command: go build -o advanced_example advanced_example.go; go-strip -s advanced_example
attacks.description: Compile a more complex Go program and apply go-strip with the -s option for additional size reduction.
attacks.expected_behavior: The advanced_example binary will be compiled and its size significantly reduced, potentially making analysis more difficult.

attacks.description: Establish a network session to simulate NTLM authentication material usage, replacing the IP address with a target machine's IP. This command does not perform an actual NTLM relay attack but demonstrates interaction with network sessions, a fundamental aspect of authentication material manipulation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to establish a network session, which may succeed or fail based on the target's configuration and the attacker's privileges.

attacks.description: This PowerShell command attempts to establish a TCP connection to a target IP address on port 445, which is associated with SMB/CIFS services and NTLM authentication. It then sends a byte array down the stream. This simulates network interaction that could be part of an NTLM relay attack setup but does not execute the attack itself.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to connect to the specified host and port, then sends data. The outcome depends on the target's network configuration and the attacker's network position.

attacks.description: This command creates a file in the temporary directory and then attempts to establish a network session with a target IP, simulating steps that might be taken in preparation for or as part of testing authentication material, including potential NTLM relay scenarios.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file and then attempts to establish a network session, which may succeed or fail based on the target's configuration and the attacker's privileges.

attacks.description: Basic NTLM relay attack to a web server
attacks.expected_behavior: Relay NTLM authentication requests to the target web server

attacks.description: Intermediate: Setting up Responder to capture NTLM hashes
attacks.expected_behavior: Capture NTLM hashes from the network, potentially leading to further exploitation

attacks.description: Advanced: Relay NTLM authentication to execute commands on a target server via SSH
attacks.expected_behavior: Execute commands on the target server using relayed NTLM authentication

attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and runs daily, writing to a temp file without causing harm.

attacks.description: Modify the existing 'Test Task' to append 'World' to the same temp file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task 'Test Task' is modified to append 'World' to the existing file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Delete the 'Test Task' scheduled task.
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task 'Test Task' is deleted, removing its entry from the task scheduler.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to add a new scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened for editing, allowing the user to add a new scheduled task

attacks.description: Schedule a task to run every minute, printing a test string to the console
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task will run every minute, printing 'Scheduled task executed' to the console

attacks.description: Remove all scheduled tasks
attacks.expected_behavior: All scheduled tasks will be removed

attacks.description: Create a new system process using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system process named TestService will be created

attacks.description: Stop a system process using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService system process will be stopped

attacks.description: Create a new system process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system process will be created running svchost.exe

attacks.description: Start the SSH daemon to demonstrate creating a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH daemon starts, allowing remote connections.

attacks.description: Modify the SSH daemon's startup settings to demonstrate modifying a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH daemon's startup settings are updated to start automatically on boot.

attacks.description: Enable the SSH daemon to start automatically on boot, demonstrating persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH daemon is configured to start automatically on the next boot.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using PowerShell to start a new cmd.exe process that writes to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test.txt will be created in the temporary directory with the content 'Test'.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "&{Add-Type -TypeDefinition 'using System;using System.Diagnostics;class P { static void Main() { Process.Start("cmd.exe"); } }'; [P]::Main() }"
attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using PowerShell to compile and execute a C# program that starts a new cmd.exe process.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cmd.exe process will be started.

attacks.description: Advanced process injection technique by utilizing rundll32.exe to load and execute a DLL (in this case, user32.dll) which can lead to code execution in the context of the rundll32.exe process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will produce a beep sound, indicating the execution of the MessageBeep function from user32.dll.

attacks.description: Inject code into a running process using gdb, allocating memory, filling it with NOPs, and then copying a small payload into it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to inject code into a process with PID 1234, potentially allowing for execution of arbitrary code within the context of that process.

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { execve("/bin/sh", ["/bin/sh"], NULL); }' > payload.c; gcc payload.c -o payload; ./payload
attacks.description: Compile a simple C program that executes a shell, demonstrating basic code injection by replacing the current process image with a new one.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command compiles a C program that, when executed, replaces the current process with a shell, effectively injecting new code into the process.

attacks.command: echo 'void __attribute__((constructor)) init() { system("/bin/sh"); }' > payload.c; gcc -shared -o payload.so -fPIC payload.c; LD_PRELOAD=./payload.so /bin/ls
attacks.description: Create a shared library that injects code into a process by utilizing the constructor attribute, which executes before main, demonstrating a more advanced form of process injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a shared library that, when preloaded by a process (in this case, /bin/ls), executes a shell before the main function of the process, injecting arbitrary code execution.

attacks.description: Lists all running services, which can be used to identify potential command and control channels.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running services

attacks.description: Creates a file in the temp directory using PowerShell, demonstrating the use of application layer protocols for command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Creates a file in the temp directory using cmd.exe, demonstrating a basic application layer protocol for command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Establish a netcat connection to a hypothetical command and control server.
attacks.expected_behavior: A connection attempt to the specified server and port.

attacks.description: Use curl to fetch a hypothetical malicious payload from a command and control server via HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: An HTTP request to the specified URL to download the payload.

attacks.description: Use ssh to execute a command on a remote server, simulating command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: Execution of the ls command on the remote server and display of the results locally.

attacks.description: Exploits a public-facing application by downloading a malicious DLL using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL to the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Exploits a public-facing application by downloading an exploit using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a specified URL to the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Exploits a public-facing application by registering a malicious script using regsvr32.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registers a script from a specified URL, potentially allowing execution of malicious code.

attacks.description: Simulate exploiting a public-facing web application using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should send a GET request to the specified URL with the exploit parameter, simulating an exploitation attempt without causing actual harm.

attacks.description: Simulate downloading and executing an exploit script from a public-facing application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should download a file (in this case, to /dev/null, which discards the output) and then attempt to execute it, simulating the exploitation process without actual payload execution due to the use of /dev/null.

attacks.description: Simulate exploiting a public-facing application using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should establish a connection to the specified host and port, then send a GET request for the exploit path, simulating an exploitation attempt without causing harm.
